circuit_intent.description: Simple ESP32-C3 minimal circuit with external 3.3V power, basic UART programming header, and a small GPIO breakout header. Includes power filtering/decoupling and an optional external 40MHz crystal network for stable clocking.

symbols.explanation: Main MCU providing compute and Wi-Fi/BLE; ESP32-C3 chosen per request for a simple ESP32-based circuit.
Simple 4-pin header for powering the board (3V3/GND) and UART programming/serial console (TX/RX).
GPIO breakout header to access multiple ESP32-C3 pins for simple prototyping and peripherals.
3.3V rail symbol required to power the ESP32-C3 and associated circuitry from the external 3.3V source.
Ground reference for the power system and signal return paths; required for any powered circuit.
Ferrite bead on the 3.3V input to reduce high-frequency noise into the MCU supply; 600ohm@100MHz is a common default for small digital rails.
Bulk decoupling for the 3.3V rail near the MCU; 10uF is a typical value to handle transient current demands.
High-frequency decoupling capacitor for the MCU supply; 0.1uF is a standard value for digital IC bypassing.
Default pull-up resistor for an enable/reset-related strap (commonly EN) to ensure the MCU boots reliably; 10k is a common pull value.
Small capacitor used as an optional RC reset/enable filter with the pull-up to improve power-on reset behavior; 0.1uF is a typical default.
Optional external crystal for more accurate/stable clocking; 40MHz is a common crystal frequency used with ESP32-class designs.
Crystal load capacitor (one side) to support Y1 oscillation; 18pF is a common starting value for 40MHz crystals depending on CL and layout.
Crystal load capacitor (other side) paired with C3 for Y1; matching 18pF values is a typical default for a balanced crystal network.
